name: Plaza de Los Héroes
address: Intersection of Estado St. and Independencia St., Rancagua, O'Higgins, Chile
description: The central square of Rancagua, historically significant as the site of the Battle of Rancagua during the Chilean War of Independence. It features monuments and is a vibrant public space.

name: Estadio El Teniente
address: Av. Bernardo O'Higgins 390, Rancagua, O'Higgins, Chile
description: A prominent multi-purpose stadium primarily used for football matches, with a capacity of over 13,000 spectators. It's home to O'Higgins F.C. and has hosted international sporting events.

name: Parque Safari Chile
address: Ruta H-30, Km. 5, Doñihue, O'Higgins, Chile (near Rancagua)
description: An animal park and zoo offering unique safari experiences where visitors can interact with animals, along with other attractions like a zip line, arcade, and restaurant. It's a popular family destination.

name: Regional Museum of Rancagua
description: Housed within two well-preserved colonial mansions, the museum showcases a collection of 19th-century furnishings, period costumes, and artifacts that provide insight into the local history and culture of the O'Higgins Region.

name: Medialuna de Rancagua
address: Avenida Libertador Bernardo O'Higgins s/n, Rancagua, O'Higgins, Chile
description: The most important 'medialuna' (half-moon shaped arena) in Chile, famous for hosting the annual National Rodeo Championship (Champion de Chile), a major cultural and sporting event celebrating Chilean huaso traditions.

name: Iglesia de la Merced
description: An 18th-century church with significant historical value, declared a National Monument. Its bell tower is particularly notable as it was where Bernardo O'Higgins awaited reinforcements during the Battle of Rancagua.

name: Sewell Mining Town (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
address: Located in the Andes Mountains, northeast of Rancagua (access typically via guided tours from Rancagua or nearby towns)
description: A former company town built by the Braden Copper Company in the early 20th century to house workers for the El Teniente copper mine. Its unique terraced, car-free urban design led to its designation as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tours offer a glimpse into its history.

name: Cachapoal Valley Wine Route
address: Various wineries located throughout the Cachapoal Valley, O'Higgins Region, Chile (south of Rancagua)
description: A renowned wine region known for its production of red wines, particularly Carmenere, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Merlot. The route comprises numerous vineyards offering tours, tastings, and a chance to experience Chilean viticulture.
